div.p: No. 545, folder 28, series 4, MS 610 Deane family papers, National Library of Australia, Canberra.

Let me offer my best felicitation, dear Mr Deane, to your so well merited election as Chieftain of the LS. of the N.SW an event of which I become only now aware. It does you infinite credit, that amidst the onerous and reponsible duties of your official position you still are able to participate in the researches for elucidating the Flora of your extensive country and fostering or conducting other science-work.

It may be that I have disappointed some workers in N.S.W.; but my strictly offical local duties have been severer during the last few years in proportion to the distress in our colony. I may not have been able to do all, that I myself wished to do for correspondents beyond this colony, but the correspondence alone takes alarge
one or two words??
space of my time, about 6000 letters that I hardly ever spend time in mere social recreation, that the day has only 24 hours, the week only 7 days, that I am entering now the eighth decade of my life, and would like during the little that can remain of my worldly career, to finish some of my own researches in the limited time, which can be made free from strict Office obligations

div.p: My own progressive time often came for a lengthened time to a stand still almost by the incessent calls on my time for examining plants, and my Department had in many instances nothing whatever to show for the sacrifice of time.

Not seldom the specimens submitted were so imperfect as to
word left out.
misleading, I remember an instance when at the first hurried glance a narrow state of a well known Erogrostis was taken by me for a Sporobolus. Hours and Hours have often been spent in the vain attempt of giving the name to a plant, the specimen[s] of which were got without the slightest care for perfection. You have been ever kind to me and ever loyal . If I at any time not answer letters, or do afford aid, all I can is this, Those who maybe discontent with me should not forget, that they use daily the works, on which the sweat of my brow adheres through 50 years and more.

In cases, when no answer to enquiries is received, my real friends should repeat their questions. I find it at time utterly impossible to over take all the work expected from me beyond the colony, to which my time is expected to be given. In one of the colonies I have encountered even not only much ingratitude, but even injury to my scientific position. But let this be buried in silence.

I hope you will be able to induce your Officers in the far N.W. to collect. The oldest writing of Bolbophyllum was not Balbophylluim Perhaps you will adopt the more legitimate spelling in the book
